so.translation[0].definitions[0].definit: used to emphasize how great a feeling or quality is, or how large an amount is
so.translation[0].definitions[0].example: Why didn’t you call? We were so worried.
so.translation[0].definitions[1].definit: as great, nice, many etc as this
so.translation[0].definitions[1].example: Why are you being so horrible to me?
I’ve never seen so many people here before!
How had they achieved it in so short a time?
so.translation[0].definitions[2].definit: used when emphasizing the degree or amount of something by saying what the result is
so.translation[0].definitions[2].example: He was so weak that he could hardly stand up.
There was so much smoke that they couldn’t see across the hallway.
Everything happened so quickly I hadn’t time to think.
The particles are so small as to be almost invisible.
so.translation[0].definitions[3].definit: used before or after a verb to emphasize that someone does something a lot or to a great degree
so.translation[0].definitions[3].example: I wish you wouldn’t fuss so  (=as much as you do). It makes me nervous.
He does so enjoy reading your letters.
so.translation[0].definitions[4].definit: used before a noun phrase to emphasize what you are saying – used especially by young people
so.translation[0].definitions[4].example: He is just so not the right person for her.
so.translation[0].definitions[5].definit: used to add that what has just been said is also true about someone or something else
so.translation[0].definitions[5].example: Joe was a little upset, and so was I.
so do I/so is he/so would Peter etc
He’s been ill, and so has his wife.
so do I/so is he/so would Peter etc
As the demand rises, so do prices.
so do I/so is he/so would Peter etc
so.translation[0].definitions[6].definit: used to refer back to an idea, action, quality, situation etc that has just been mentioned
so.translation[0].definitions[6].example: The troops will not advance until ordered to do so.
Did Luke sell them? And, if so, what happened to the money?
‘Has he lost a fortune?’ ‘So they say.’
‘Look – I’ve even cleaned the windows.’ ‘So I see.’
Parents can withdraw their child from school if they so wish.
‘Will I need my umbrella?’ ‘I don’t think so.’
If you want to go home, just say so.
The band is popular and likely to become more so.
be more so/less so/too much so
Jerry is very honest, perhaps too much so.
be more so/less so/too much so
so.translation[0].definitions[7].definit: used to get someone’s attention, especially in order to ask them a question
so.translation[0].definitions[8].definit: used to check that you have understood something
so.translation[0].definitions[8].example: So this is just a copy?
so.translation[0].definitions[9].definit: used when asking a question about what has just been said
so.translation[0].definitions[9].example: ‘He’s going to Paris on business.’ ‘So when is he coming back?’
so.translation[0].definitions[10].defini: used with a movement of your hand to show how big, high etc something or someone is
so.translation[0].definitions[10].exampl: Oh, he’s about so tall, with brown hair and eyes.
so.translation[0].definitions[11].defini: used to show that you have found something out about someone
so.translation[0].definitions[11].exampl: So! You’ve got a new girlfriend?
so.translation[0].definitions[12].defini: in the way that is described
so.translation[0].definitions[12].exampl: Dorothy and Sarah continued to write to each other, and so began a lifelong friendship.
The furniture is so arranged that the interviewee and the interviewer are not physically separated by a desk.
so.translation[0].definitions[13].defini: used to say that a person’s behaviour or action is typical of that person
so.translation[0].definitions[13].exampl: ‘He was about half an hour late.’ ‘That is just so Chris.’
so.translation[0].definitions[14].defini: used to say that something suits someone or is the type of thing they like
so.translation[0].definitions[14].exampl: You must buy that jacket – it’s so you!
so.translation[0].definitions[15].defini: used to introduce the next part of a story you are telling someone
so.translation[0].definitions[15].exampl: So anyway, he goes in and his boots get stuck in the mud.
so.translation[1].definitions[0].definit: used to tell someone that something does not matter
so.translation[1].definitions[0].example: So what if we’re a little late?
‘She might tell someone.’ ‘So? No one will believe her.’
so.translation[2].definitions[0].definit: used to say that someone does something because of the reason just stated
so.translation[2].definitions[0].example: I was feeling hungry, so I made myself a sandwich.
so.translation[2].definitions[0].note_bo: In written English, people often prefer to use therefore or consequently rather than so, because they sound more formal:
She had previous experience, therefore she seemed the best candidate.
